title: Slidr
text:
Slidr
In today's world,

title: Slidr
text:
Powerpoint Fe 
My first stop was Italy, a country renowned for its rich culinary heritage. I was instantly drawn to their authentic pizzas, prepared in wood-fired ovens, and the variety of pasta dishes, each telling a story of a different region. The simplicity of Italian cuisine, emphasizing fresh, quality ingredients, was a refreshing change from the heavily processed meals we often consume.

title: Slidr
text:
Slide Fitting vs Slide Generation 
Next, I ventured into the vibrant world of Indian cuisine. Known for its bold, complex flavors and diverse range of dishes, Indian food was a treat for my taste buds. From the spicy curries of the North to the tangy rasam of the South, Indian food is a testament to the country's rich cultural diversity and history.

title: Slidr
text:
Sushi and Beyond: Japan
Lastly, my culinary journey took me to Japan, a country that blends tradition and innovation in its cuisine. While sushi is undoubtedly the poster child of Japanese food, I was intrigued by other dishes such as ramen, tempura, and the delicate kaiseki meals. The meticulous preparation and presentation of each dish was a sight to behold, reflecting the Japanese philosophy of treating food with respect.

title: Slidr
text:
The Fusion of Flavors: Mexico
Moving on from Japan, my taste buds were welcomed by the fiery flavors of Mexico. Known for its delicious tacos, enchiladas, and guacamole, Mexican cuisine is a perfect blend of indigenous Mesoamerican and European cooking techniques. The use of staples like corn, beans, and chili peppers in their dishes gives them a distinct taste, one that left me yearning for more.

title: Slidr
text:
Aromatic Journey: Thailand
My culinary expedition then took me to Thailand, a country celebrated for its aromatic dishes. Thai cuisine is a balance of five flavors: sour, sweet, salty, bitter, and spicy. Their famous Pad Thai and Green Curry offered an explosion of flavors, leaving an unforgettable mark on my food journey.

title: Slidr
text:
Savoring Simplicity: France
France, often considered the culinary capital of the world, was my next stop. French cuisine is all about simplicity and quality ingredients. Whether it was the hearty coq au vin or the delicate crème brûlée, each dish was a masterpiece in its own right, reflecting the French's profound respect for food.

title: Slidr
text:
Epilogue
In conclusion, each cuisine has a story to tell, each dish a culture to represent. As I continue my gastronomic journey, I am excited to explore more cuisines, to taste their unique flavors, and to learn the stories behind them. Because exploring new cuisines is not just about tantalizing your taste buds, but also about experiencing different cultures, traditions, and histories.

title: My Favorite Hobbies: How I Spend My Free Time

In my freshman year of college, i was torn. I sought the rigour, camaraderie and thrill of competitive team sport, but also wanted to explore while understanding the limitations of my body. After having suffering multiple injures from __, it was quite evident that my physicality, could not match my fervour for ____. That was when i stumbled upon the world of Poomsae and Taekwondo. Little did i know, i would soon be representing my university in varsity level competitions, and training with and befriending the most wonderful people.

title: My Favorite Hobbies: How I Spend My Free Time

Berkeley, joined Blueprint

title: My Favorite Hobbies: How I Spend My Free Time
text:
Conclusion
In conclusion, hobbies are more than just pastimes. They provide a break from our regular routines, allow us to learn new skills, and add joy and fulfillment to our lives. Each one of my hobbies – reading, gardening, and cooking – has enriched my free time, nurtured my personal growth, and brought me immense pleasure. By sharing my favorite hobbies, I hope to inspire you to pursue activities that bring you happiness and satisfaction. After all, life is not just about surviving, but also about enjoying and making the most of our free time.

title: Summer 2025
text:
Summer 2025
Last summer,

title: Summer 2025
text:
DSO
Positive thinking revolves around the intriguing process of manifesting thoughts that create and transform energy into reality. It represents a mental and emotional attitude that focuses unwaveringly on the bright side of life and constantly expects positive results.

title: Summer 2025
text:
DSO
Positive thinking is absolutely not about pretending that life's less pleasant situations simply don't exist. It's not about turning a blind eye to the negative. Rather, it's about approaching these less than ideal situations in a more positive and productive way, firmly believing that the best is going to happen, not the worst. It's about viewing the glass as half-full rather than half-empty. It's about seeing problems as challenges and viewing these challenges as opportunities to grow, learn and evolve.

title: Summer 2025
text:
Margaret River 
Positive thinking brings with it a veritable wealth of psychological benefits. It has the potential to significantly enhance your mood and broaden your sense of possibility. This, in turn, allows you to develop and build new skills and resources that can provide immense value in other areas of your life.

title: Summer 2025
text:
Margaret River 
There's a growing body of research to support the benefits of positive thinking. Studies have shown that a positive mindset can lead to better stress management and coping strategies, lower levels of depression, and even an increased life span. It's not just mental health that can benefit from positive thinking. Physical health can improve too. Positive thinking can improve cardiovascular health and notably reduce the risk of death from cardiovascular disease.

title: Summer 2025
text:
Landing Page 
Cultivating positive thinking is not a passive process. It's a habit that requires consistent practice, patience, and commitment. Start by identifying areas of your life that you usually think negatively about and make a conscious effort to spin them into something positive.

title: Summer 2025
text:
Landing Page 
Surround yourself with positive people who inspire and uplift you. Practice positive self-talk, and make it a point to start each and every day on a positive note. Set the tone for the day with positivity and watch how it influences your interactions, your work, and your relationships.

title: Summer 2025
text:
Landing Page 
It's also important to remember that it's okay to have negative thoughts sometimes. We're all human, and it's not about eliminating all negative thoughts. It's about not letting them control you, not letting them dictate your emotions, and not letting them affect your outlook on life.

title: Summer 2025
text:
Conclusion
The power of positive thinking is immense and far-reaching. It has the potential to transform your mental, emotional, and physical health, open up new opportunities, and lead you down a path of success and fulfillment. Remember, the mind is an incredibly powerful tool, and the thoughts we harbor within it can shape our reality. So, foster positivity, nurture it, and watch how it profoundly changes your life for the better.

title: About Me
text:
General Background
I am a third-year Computer Engineering student at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore, currently on exchange at the University of California, Berkeley. I have completed several internships and am actively involved in college clubs and societies, where I enjoy working in dynamic, collaborative environments. I am deeply passionate about innovative technology—especially when it can be applied meaningfully to create positive real-world impact. Beyond academics and work, I enjoy staying active and creative. I play basketball, compete in varsity-level Taekwondo competitions, and am training as an aspiring triathlete. I also play electric bass in a band and have performed at several university events. I thrive in fast-paced, rigorous environments and am driven by curiosity, exploration, and new experiences.

title: About Me
text:
Passion & Interests
I am passionate about meaningful technology.

title: About Me
text:
Experience
I have completed several internships across startups, public-sector organizations, and deep-tech research environments, which have collectively shaped my technical foundation and understanding of how technology is applied at scale.

title: About Me
text:
Experience
Last summer, I worked at DSO, where I was involved in improving existing systems in collaboration with a third-party Hardware-as-a-Service (HaaS) provider. My work focused on increasing computational efficiency by leveraging GPU-based systems, particularly through parallelising clustering algorithms on a HIP-based GPU architecture. I researched and implemented clustering techniques such as DBSCAN, HDBSCAN, and Mean-Shift, and benchmarked their performance using simulated datasets. This experience deepened my understanding of high-performance computing, parallel algorithms, and the practical challenges of deploying GPU-accelerated systems.

title: About Me
text:
Experience
In my second internship, I worked at the Land Transport Authority (LTA) as an Artificial Intelligence Intern. As a mature organization, LTA placed strong emphasis on upskilling and educating its officers on the evolving state of AI and modern technologies. I conducted in-depth research across multiple areas of deep learning, including artificial neural networks, convolutional neural networks, generative AI, retrieval-augmented generation, and reinforcement learning. I then distilled these concepts into clear, accessible explanations tailored for non-technical audiences. Alongside this, I completed several deep learning courses to strengthen my technical foundation, an experience I found both challenging and highly rewarding.

title: About Me
text:
Experience
My first internship was at a startup focused on gamifying the shopping experience, where I worked as a Business Development and Automation Intern. While my primary responsibility involved lead generation and sales pitching, I also took initiative in improving internal workflows through automation. I developed tools to streamline lead generation and onboarding processes, automated CRM workflows using JavaScript, and learned Google Apps Script to build systems that enabled large-scale outreach emails. Additionally, I automated the onboarding pipeline by creating scheduled reminder, chaser, and follow-up emails, significantly improving operational efficiency.

title: About Me
text:
Education 
I am a third-year Computer Engineering student at Nanyang Technological Uiversity (NTU) in Singapore, currently on exchange at the University of California, Berkeley. I am in my penultimate year and expect to graduate in 2027. At UC Berkeley, I have taken technically rigorous courses including Efficient Algorithms and Intractable Problems, Feedback Control Systems, Control Theory and Reinforcement Learning, Databases, and Computer Networks, which strengthened my foundations in algorithms, systems, and control.

title: About Me
text:
Education 
At NTU, my coursework focuses on core computer engineering and software fundamentals, including Data Structures and Algorithms, Algorithm Design and Analysis, Object-Oriented Design and Programming, Software Engineering, Introduction to Data Science and Artificial Intelligence, Microprocessor System Design and Development, and Digital Systems Design. In addition to technical training, I have completed non-technical modules such as Fundamentals of Management, Accounting for Managerial Decisions, Science and Technology for Humanity, and Foundations of Engineering Leadership, which inform my approach to leadership and decision-making.

title: About Me
text:
Extra Curriculars
Blueprint (UC Berkeley)

title: About Me
text:
Extra Curriculars
At UC Berkeley, I joined Blueprint, a technology club that partners with non-profits to build impactful software solutions. As a developer, I worked with a team to design and implement a full-stack application that digitises tabletop exercises used to train and evaluate emergency response workflows during pandemic outbreaks. From a technical standpoint, the system features a Next.js frontend, Supabase for database management and orchestration of real-time asynchronous operations, and is deployed on Vercel. The project emphasised reliability, real-time coordination, and reusability across emergency preparedness scenarios.

title: About Me
text:
Extra Curriculars
REACH (NTU)

title: About Me
text:
Extra Curriculars
At NTU, I am part of REACH, an engineering club focused on developing assistive technologies for the differently abled in collaboration with organisations such as AWWA and MDAS. The club runs approximately seven active projects each academic year, and I am directly involved in two of them. My primary project aims to improve visual testing workflows in hospitals through an integrated hardware–software system. The software component is built in Python using PyQt6 for the graphical user interface and computer vision pipelines involving filtering, cascade thresholding, and vectorised operations for efficiency. The hardware component uses an Arduino interfaced with servo motors, lasers, and haptic and feedback devices such as buttons, buzzers, and lights, with real-time communication between hardware and software handled via serial communication.

title: The Evolution of EyeTracker
text:
The Context
Glaucoma is a chronic, progressive optic neuropathy and is the leading cause of irreversible blindness worldwide. Key to the management of glaucoma is the accurate and precise assessment of visual field (VF) function to detect VF loss from glaucoma and to monitor disease progression, which impacts important clinical decisions with respect to medication titration, laser procedures and even surgery. VF function is monitored commonly with automated perimetry; This utilises light stimulus and requires similar user interactions to evaluate the user’s VF.

title: The Evolution of EyeTracker
text:
The Problem 
The reliability of VF testing is critical in ensuring meaningful results which will accurately inform clinical management decisions. Reliability is often difficult to achieve, due to the initial learning curve for the patients, as well as variability in patient understanding and executing the test protocols. Current practices rely heavily on explanation and attention of the attending ophthalmic technician, and patient comprehension and cooperation – both of which may be highly variable, leading to unreliable results that can compromise the accuracy of disease monitoring. This undermines efforts to optimise treatment strategies tailored to individual patient needs.

title: The Evolution of EyeTracker
text:
The Problem 
In real-world clinical setting, appointment slots for VF testing are often limited by manpower and availability of testing devices. VF testing is a relatively time-consuming and tedious process, taking up to 10 minutes per patient, depending on the testing algorithm used. This does not include additional time required for equipment set up, patient transfer and explanation of testing process. Hence, when a patient’s VF test results are unreliable, resource constraints make it challenging to schedule a retest in close time proximity. This leads to an inefficient use of appointment slots for the clinic, and a missed opportunity to collect valuable data for the patient’s care. This would delay diagnosis or detection of disease progression.

title: The Evolution of EyeTracker
text:
The Problem Breakdown
To tackle this problem, we first spoke to ophthalmologists to identify the gaps in current practices. After extensive discussion, we broke the problem down into two parts: Instruction and Execution.

title: The Evolution of EyeTracker
text:
The Problem Breakdown
Instruction:

title: The Evolution of EyeTracker
text:
The Problem Breakdown
The patients in which these ophthalmologists have the most trouble with, are usually the elderly. With this group of people, struggles usually originate from a communicative breakdown. Due to the relative complexity of the test, significant time is spent on clarification. This problem is also exacerbated by potential language barriers and/or hearing impairments.

title: The Evolution of EyeTracker
text:
The Problem Breakdown
Execution:

title: The Evolution of EyeTracker
text:
The Problem Breakdown
Given the enclosed nature of the test and that results are not known until the end of the 10 minute long procedure, doctors or nurses would not be able to consistently track and correct any mistakes in execution. Hence, any misunderstandings, unconscious habits or errors will go unidentified and only be reflected in via a failed test.

title: The Evolution of EyeTracker
text:
The Problem Breakdown
Hence, we to sufficiently address both parts of the problem, we decided to 1. Create a simplified instructional video to relay information and 2. Make a pre-assessment simulation booth for patients to familiarise with test procedures and environment as well as nurses to identify any potential misunderstandings or errors.

title: The Evolution of EyeTracker
text:
The Problem Breakdown
This solution should provide standardised, user-friendly instruction for patients, accompanied by hands-on practical practice with immediate sensory or tactile feedback.

title: The Evolution of EyeTracker
text:
The Problem Breakdown
In totality, this aims to reduce the VF testing learning curve for patients and enhance patient education - thereby improving reliability and consistency of test outcomes.

title: The Evolution of EyeTracker
text:
The Early Prototype
Run in Terminal, Simple one stop UX Visualiser system

title: The Evolution of EyeTracker
text:
The Early Prototype

Our initial prototype consisted of several components. In our design, we aimed to adapt current technologies to reduce friction and workload.

title: The Evolution of EyeTracker
text:
The Early Prototype
Visualiser to screen dots on a white back ground Camera with pupil tracking capabilities Basic electronics such as an Arduino with some buttons to record presses and a buzzer to provide haptic feedback on erroneous presses. Some dark box to ensure ample illumination from the visualiser

title: The Evolution of EyeTracker
text:
The Early Prototype
Some major challenges we faced:

title: The Evolution of EyeTracker
text:
The Early Prototype
Camera placement Illumination Sample rate and pupil tracker accuracy

title: The Evolution of EyeTracker
text:
Mid-course correction
Consulted ophthalmologists and realised flaws with lightning, not intuitive One step further in, utilise existing neck support, box architecture,

title: The Evolution of EyeTracker
text:
The HI-FI
‘Laser Turret’ to shine spots at particular coordinates  Staged PyQt6 GUI, more intuitive UX, build initialise, start stop into GUI, do not need to touch the terminal Calibration stage to adjust for differences for each patient.  Adapted pupil tracker with vectorised calculations 3D Printed Box

title: The Evolution of EyeTracker
text:
Learning Points
technical growth exposure fancy technical architecture not important, just need to fulfil user requriements, meet user standards

title: The Evolution of EyeTracker
text:
What Now?
GPU integration with PCB for fast processing of images. Allow more calculations more accurate detection of pupil, allow more light correction and editing. Actual user testing, to identify painpoints.
